Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for the 2016 Southeastern Regional Meeting of ACS Symposium "New Chemistries towards Functional Polymeric Materials", Columbia, SC October 23 - 26, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL AND NONTECHNICAL ABSTRACT
Funds in the amount of $2,540 are requested to support the registration fee and travel expenses of attendees at the Symposium on "New Chemistries towards Functional Polymeric Materials" to be held at the 2016 Southern Regional meeting of the ACS (SERMACS) in South Carolina October 23-26, 2016. The symposium will cover the latest progress in using chemistry strategies for developing functional polymeric materials, including monomer design, synthesis, polymerization methodologies for architecture and composition control, and the chemical modification of polymers. The symposium provides a platform for the exchange of expertise and ideas by academic and industrial organic chemistry and polymer scientists from the southeastern region, and having an educational impact on attending graduate students as well as postdocs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has supported scientists to attend a "New Chemistries towards Functional Polymeric Materials" at the Southeastern Regional Meeting of American Chemical Society (SERMACS), which was held in Columbia SC, October 23-26, 2016.

I participated quite a few Polymer Symposiums in the past SERMACS. Some of them are very interesting. However, many of these symposiums suffer low participation from regional scientists. In many cases, oral presentations can only attract a few audience. One of the major obstacles is  how to bring active senior scientists from the region to present a cohesive program that is sufficiently attractive to students and industry scientists. I planned to execute this goal into a very successful symposium and hoped that it could set up an example for future organizers to do the similar initiative. Certainly, the goal was to facilitate the regional dialogue, promote collaboration, educate students and engage with the communities.

A good symposium needs an appropriate, attractive and perhaps niche topic that could cover sufficiently broad areas. When we look at polymer scientists in the Southeastern region, there are many excellent research programs in different universities. People work on different areas for various applications. However, an ongoing trend is to rely on innovative chemistry to design new polymeric materials for fundamental physicochemical study. That was the initial reason I proposed the symposium topic on chemistry towards polymeric materials.

We successfully invited scientists from 11 universities and colleges across the Southeastern region for one and half day sessions. In addition, we also invited one speaker from the Great New York area to embrace our openness. The symposium was designed to give opportunities to junior faculty and students. Thus, we have 5 talks given by assistant professors; 2 by graduate students; as well as 1 by a faculty from a Primarily Undergraduate Institution (PUI). In addition, 2 female faculty were invited, including an African American. We have received tremendous interest from graduate students and undergraduates. There were 28 posters covering a variety of topics. These talks and posters include research in the following areas: polymers for optoelectronics, antifouling, oil-extracting, li-ion batteries, sensing, templating, sustainability, anti-cancer treatment, hybrid materials, and carbon fibers; synthetic methods toward mechanochemistry, living cationic polymers and organoboron polymers.

Due to the well planning and “advertisement” of this symposium, each oral talk was well participated. On average, each session drew more than 50 audiences. The poster session also received strong attention. Particularly it was well visited by industry scientists. 

Outcomes

Overall, I felt the initial goal was achieved. This symposium provided an energized platform for regional scientists to communicate their work and promote mutual collaboration. Students had a great opportunity to present their research and socialize with various scientists. The local communities took notes on the polymer activities. More importantly this symposium could set up an excellent example on how to organize a successful regional symposium that truly has a positive impact. It is the hope that future polymer symposiums at SERMACS could continue its excellency to make impact on the regional research and society of polymers.

Broader Impact

This Symposium on “New Chemistries towards Functional Polymeric Materials” provided a platform for the exchange of expertise and ideas within this field and facilitates the discovery of new research directions. This symposium generated knowledge that certainly benefit a wide spectrum of participants such as graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and professors as well as researchers from government and industry laboratories. This forum brought together polymer junior faculty in the southeastern region to promote more collaborations and dialogue. The symposium also provided our Nation’s talented graduate students a platform for networking opportunities, such as interactions with academic leaders and industry R & D personnel.
